content.description:
Start up large holds through easy terrain (but harder than you would expect) to the alcove. Head slightly left out of the alcove through the powerful first crux to gain the mid-height under cling. From here things get thin and sustained for a couple of bolt to bolt sequences- probably no sequence harder than 5.12c, but the fatigue stacks up quick! The climb eases up high on the slopers, but it's definitely not over until you clip the chains!



Look for the arete on the right side of the West facing portion of the wall. This line is the first face bolt line left of the arete (easiest to spot as the bolt line that exits slightly left of the alcove)

10 bolts, cold shuts

Pumpy, juggy, super fun and even offers some mini crack and nimble finger maneuvers depending on the way you choose. A nice break from the pinchy nearby slab. Top is very obvious/clear. Not the best for top rope as there are some sharp rock/rope drag potentials so keep an eye out! 

** note there is a loose rock at 3/4 route in that is still unable to be removed and is often sought as a right hand hold. 



West-facing, farthest left on tippling tower. Boulder-looking moves between 2x 5.13s. Maneuvers along under 2 roofs. Shares an alternative start with Just Another Relapse 5.13 to its left. 

6 bolts, 2 chain anchors

Great climb, begins with 12-Step Derailer but then splits right up the the blunted arete. Hard technical moves, pretty sustained. The finish might feel a tad run-out after clipping a bolt every 4 feet. 



Same start as 12-Step Derailer.


10 bolts + anchor.

Amazingly exposed and fun for the grade. Up a series of overhanging ledges with a bunch of air underneath your feet. Huge fun, get on it.

It's the southernmost route on the crag, basically facing south where the other routes on the crag face west. Tackle the arete.
9 bolts. I couldn't find the anchors from the ground, but you *can* see them. Runners on bolts 2, 3 and 5 might help with drag.
The west-facing sport crag at the north end of the Doctor's Wall gully.
